in the boundary program back in February.
And what happened was that so the Go implementation is using a Go Lamb begin for the block number.
And there's an upcode, an instruction in the virtual machine to get the block number on
the stack.
And what happened was that you could actually put a block number that was bigger than 32
bytes there in your block header.
That would actually be valid when you deserialized the block header from the RNP encoding that
Vitalik mentioned in his previous talk.
So you could set the block number to more than 32 bytes.
And then when you grab that number on the stack, it would actually be casted in a way
that you could push a negative integer on the stack.
This was an example of how we kind of used the wrong data type in the sense that the
theme virtual machine is not defined to be, I mean, like, big integer, it's defined to
just be 256 bit values.
But in languages like Go, you kind of have to use a big integer to model that.
So the error is actually what we can see the Go for looking at here, which is the commented
code to make sure that what we push back on the stack is an inside integer.
And the thing we see at the bottom there is actually the contract bytecode that would
trigger this issue.
And the result was that you could actually create unlimited amounts of ether.
Another short example is just a very simple integer overflow that was found back in March.
This one was found by the security auditors, the security.
And it was related to the sign extend operator in the jail paper, which is used to extend
an integer, by no integer, without changing the value or the sign.
And so what the Go client used to do back in March is that it converted, it popped one
of the arguments from the stack and would then cast that to an inside integer of 64 bits,
even though stack items are 256 bits.
So that was something you could easily overflow as an attacker.
And that would then cause a consensus issue with C++ clients or the Python client.
So we had a lot of these issues where we were just casting big integers to unsciences for

So the miners basically vote, and they can change the gas limit to go up or down, but
only within a certain interval.
And this is the different GitHub for the fix to this issue.
So what happened was that we were not considering the case when the gas limit was going down,
only when it was going up.

The clients were correct in the logic, but they had a very unperformant part related
to the jump-test instruction.
And you could trigger this by making this contract where there's a single function that
calls itself.
So you could pass it like 1000, it would just call itself 1000 times.
And each time it calls itself, it makes a external function call to make sure that you

And if you compile this and then post compilation manually insert jump-test instructions in

and C++ were using a data type to store basically jump-test during the execution of

And one more thing to notice is that the cost is really cheap for a jump-test, so you just
pay a single gas for one jump-test.
And so what happened is that they were both using a set data type to store all the jump-test.
And when you had a new execution environment in the virtual machine, like when you do a
external function call, that data type was basically recreated.
So in a single transaction execution of the same contract, you would have to be recreated.
So what was changed here was basically to use a map instead and also to cache it between
